content:
This is way too complicated for a reverse clash.
There is nothing intuitive about it.

I just got it in a clash and the only people who solved it were the two bots. I came 3rd with 77% by finding some very confusing patterns that worked some of the time, but I couldn't figure out the true pattern.

It's very misleading that the amount of the words "left" and "right" shown don't mean anything (I thought there must be some logic to this), and it also doesn't mean anything whether the start, middle or end of the word is shown.

There is too much pointless complications to this clash that makes it very annoying to get as a clash. One person got 44% in my clash, and the other 4 all got 0%. It's really not a coding challenge at all, it's just a very complicated lateral thinking puzzle...

The fact that you also need to take the answer modulo 100, and the pattern is about "2*x-y" where x and y swap depending on whether part of the word "left" or "right" is shown is just not at all intuitive and makes for a boring, frustrating clash.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: type d'exercice peu vu et novateur

I suggest getting rid of the capital letters for the operation text. It adds an unnecessary level of complexity. It's annoying to some users who may miss the difference and submit after seeing that they start to pass some testcases all because they didn't convert to lowercase.

Besides that one thing, good clash!

Looking at the test cases, I knew the mathematical operations used on the numbers but had no clue about the conditions until I looked at the solution. Maybe include strings that aren't in 'left' or 'right' to clarify the conditions better? Otherwise good clash, challenging yet solvable :)
this one is tricky ! no way i can find the answer in 15 minutes

Ok maybe I need to make the string below the numbers a bit longer (test cases 5 and 6 'le' 'ri' don't ring a bell?) - let me just wait for some others that find it too hard as well. Thanks for your feedback in any case.

Thanks for your reply! I deliberately only include strings part of 'left' and 'right', because that is the only two operations (either guess the number left of the two given numbers, or the number right of the two given numbers). If I would give a string not part of left or right, I would not know what behavior to associate with that (I could make it 'none' - but that would at the same time add complexity to the clash).

In any case, your feedback together with silence from others is an important signal that this clash might have not clear enough hints. I am thinking about turning the strings just all into 'left' or 'right' (possibly with capital variations). What do you think?

You are right - due to your comment I checked this again, and it is indeed somewhat annoying that only from test/validator 7 I suddenly introduced capital letters. Thanks for pointing it out; I've changed all to lower case.

Ah, thanks a lot for your feedback, and apologies! I was somewhat hesitant about the format, but then it got three approvals after all. However, your feedback made me realize that something I just added in as extra complexity (not 'left' and 'right', but only part of it), lets reverse players wonder whether that implies a pattern.

I am going to change it all to 'left' and 'right' fully spelled out right away, so that the focus can be fully on getting the left and right, and the modulo.
Thank you, that's definitely a major improvement. I spent a fair bit of time trying to understand what the partial words meant for the solution.
Ok, I've made the strings a bit longer - better now?
